title: Don't gamble with the North East's future - The Journal says vote Remain
text:
Don't gamble with the North East's future - The Journal says vote Remain 18:30, 22 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker The future is bright for the North East but it will be out at risk if we take a gamble and leave the EU Shares Get daily news by email The front page of The Journal on June 23, 2016 
There’s nothing more that David Cameron, Jeremy Corbyn or any other politician can do. The power is in your hands. 
Today’s vote on whether we stay in the European Union will determine the future of the United Kingdom for generations to come. 
Right now, the future for the North East is bright. And the stakes are too high for a gamble which could change all that. 
Because that’s exactly what a vote for Brexit is – a throw of the dice using North East jobs and our children’s future as gambling chips. 
Our busy ports are Britain’s gateway to the world. That’s why the North East is the only region with a positive balance of trade - meaning we export more than we import. 
Foreign firms such as Nissan have so much confidence in the North East that they’ve invested literally billions of pounds here, while the region is at the heart of the UK’s energy sector. Owen Humphreys/PA Wire Workers at Nissan's plant in Sunderland on the production line 
The North East is home to 6,000 digital businesses. And with firms like Virgin Money in Newcastle, it also has a growing financial services industry. 
And we’re home to some of the best universities in the world. 
We know there is poverty and other problems too. 
But the North East is proud and successful - and we can only tackle the challenges we face if we have a strong economy behind us. 
Why risk it all with an unnecessary leap into the dark by leaving the European Union? 
The EU hasn’t held us back. It’s helped us. 
Across the region there are developments which create jobs and were built with EU money. 
Portobello Trade Park in Durham is one example. The Core Science Central in Newcastle city centre is another - and there are many more. 
The Core at Newcastle Science Central 
It’s true that the UK contributes to the EU. Yes, we put money in and then get it back. 
But the alternative is that spending decisions would be made by central government instead. And there’s no reason to imagine it would be more generous to the North East. 
In fact, it could be said that Brussels has been a better friend than London to Northumberland and County Durham, Tyne and Wear and the Tees Valley. 
The North East looks beyond Europe. 
Managers at Newcastle Airport , a vital part of the economy with big plans for the future, will tell you that. 
But being part of Europe helps us win trade and investment from across the globe. 
Japanese firm Hitachi couldn’t have put it more plainly in its statement on the referendum, when it said: “Hitachi, like other multinationals, invested in the UK in order to access the whole of the EU market, and unimpeded access to the EU market is fundamental for our position in the UK.” AP Photo/Geert Vanden Wijngaert British Prime Minister David Cameron speaks 
It’s EU membership that gives us access to the EU market - all those people in France, Germany, Italy and Spain who want to buy things made here in the North East. 
What do anti-EU campaigners offer instead? A vague promise that if we quit then we’ll be able to negotiate a new deal giving us access to European markets again. 
But they can’t guarantee that. And they certainly can’t tell us how long it will take, because they just don’t know. 
This isn’t a game. This is a real threat to the prosperity and success of our industries, our institutions and our communities here in the North East. 
That’s why everyone from the heads of our universities to employers big and small, the region’s top scientists, premier league football clubs and the Bishop of Durham is urging Britain to vote to remain in the EU. 
The Union Jack flag flies besides the flag of the European Union 
Set against a positive vision of a successful North East in the European Union is the “leave” campaign’s vision of our country - frightened and turning its back on the world. 
They say that millions of Turks are set to invade Britain if we stay in the EU. But this is just fearmongering. Turkey is not joining the EU for the foreseeable future, because of its poor human rights record. 
We can’t cut ourselves off from our neighbours. And we can’t put our jobs and exports at risk, as the leave campaign wants us to do. 
The North East is strong and successful when it looks out across the world, trading, attracting investment and collaborating. 
We do that best as part of the European Union. 
And that’s why the best way to safeguard the future of this region, our families and generations to come is to vote “remain” today. The European Union debate
